page.title: 03The River South Esk.
page.content: The South Esk,one of Scotlands finest trout and salmon rivers runs past Tannadice on its journey from the Grampian Mountains to the North Sea. The source of the South Esk lies on the south facing slopes of Cairn Bannoch at an elevation of above one thousand metres.During the seventy to eighty kilometres of its course the Esk is strengthened by many tributaries,the largest of these being the White Water of Glen Doll and the Prosen water of Glen Prosen. The course of the South Esk has been long used as a route connecting the fertile lowlands of the Mearns with the highland glens of the North.Along this route stand many castles some now ruined,as the castle of Clova,some still occupied,as the fine castle of Cortachy.
